description: Content Security Policy (CSP) helps to mitigate certain security threats, including cross-site scripting (XSS) and clickjacking attacks. It consists of a set of directives from a website to a browser, which instruct the browser to restrict the things that the site is allowed to do.
description_html: Content Security Policy (CSP) helps to mitigate certain security threats, including cross-site scripting (XSS) and clickjacking attacks. It consists of a set of directives from a website to a browser, which instruct the browser to restrict the things that the site is allowed to do.
name: Content Security Policy (CSP)

safari.notes: The property is defined only for its useful elements: <link>, <script>, and <style>; it is undefined for all other elements.

safari_ios.notes: The property is defined only for its useful elements: <link>, <script>, and <style>; it is undefined for all other elements.

webview_ios.notes: The property is defined only for its useful elements: <link>, <script>, and <style>; it is undefined for all other elements.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 50, ping attributes of <a> elements weren't covered by connect-src.

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox for Android 58, frame-ancestors is ignored in Content-Security-Policy-Report-Only.

chrome.notes: Chrome 59 and higher skips the deprecated child-src directive.

chrome_android.notes: Chrome Android 59 and higher skips the deprecated child-src directive.

oculus.notes: Quest Browser 5.0 and higher skips the deprecated child-src directive.

opera.notes: Opera 46 and higher skips the deprecated child-src directive.

opera_android.notes: Opera Android 43 and higher skips the deprecated child-src directive.

webview_android.notes: WebView Android 59 and higher skips the deprecated child-src directive.
